channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Cost of the U.S. Ban on Paying for Hostages
item.description: Former hostages and Syrian rebel commanders say that they offered information they believed could help free American captives, but that officials seemed uninterested.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Louai Abo Aljoud, a 23-year-old Syrian journalist who was held with James Foley, outside his home in Gaziantep, Turkey. He says that after he was released, he tried to give American officials information about the prison's location.

item.title: As Crisis Saps Economy, Belarus Replaces Premier
item.description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus dismissed his prime minister and the head of the country’s central bank on Saturday as part of a sweeping and unexpected government reorganization.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mikhail Myasnikovich in 2013, before his dismissal by the Belarussian president.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Facebook Deletes Post on Tibetan Monk’s Self-Immolation
item.description: Tsering Woeser, a writer in Sichuan Province and prominent critic of Chinese policies toward Tibetans, said Facebook deleted her post on the self-immolation of the 37-year-old monk Kalsang Yeshi, without explanation.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Sweden Strikes Deal to Avoid Vote Expected to Strengthen Far Right
item.description: Sweden’s mainstream political parties announced a deal on Saturday to preserve a minority center-left government by adopting the center-right’s budget for next year.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: In Limbo, a City in China Faces Life After Graft
item.description: The town of Lüliang in Shanxi Province, whose coal helped fuel China’s economic boom, is at the center of a crackdown that challenges the close ties between business and government.
item.dc:creator: By IAN JOHNSON

item.title: As Syria’s Revolution Sputters, a Chaotic Stalemate
item.description: The battleground of Syria’s war is increasingly divided between the government and extremists, leaving many Syrians feeling that the revolution on which they gambled has failed.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mosque that has served as a rallying point for insurgents in the Khalidiya District of Homs, Syria.

item.title: Putin's Way: Even Loyalty No Guarantee Against Putin
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, who wields virtually unchallenged power to reward a new class of oligarchs, also uses the same instrument to punish those who oppose him.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS and JO BECKER
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Listen, I’ve done everything I can for you. Good luck.” — , a self-exiled Russian banker, on what President Vladimir V. Putin told him as his financial empire crumbled.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Stargazing Is Better in the Southern Hemisphere
item.description: Our constellations may be upside down, but our stars shine brighter.
item.dc:creator: By VANESSA BARBARA
item.media:credit: Babak Tafreshi/National Geographic Society, via Corbis
item.media:description: The Southern Cross, Milky Way, Large Magellanic Cloud and Carina Nebula, viewed from Kenya.

item.title: Japan Unveils $29 Billion Stimulus Package
item.description: Analysts were skeptical about how much the spending, which avoided issuing fresh debt and included subsidies, merchandise vouchers and lower mortgage rates, could spur growth.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
item.media:description: Voters gave Prime Minister Shinzo Abe a new mandate.

item.title: Syria to Discuss Russia Peace Plan Talks
item.description: Members of the Western-backed Syrian opposition dismissed the Russian plan on Saturday, however, saying there was “no initiative.”
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Letter From Europe: Shining Light on an Era’s Darker Side
item.description: The death of Mandy Rice-Davies, who played a starring role in the Profumo affair, evoked much more than a vicarious return to moments that defined their times.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Mandy Rice-Davies with Christine Keeler at the height of scandal in 1963.

item.title: Double Blow for Parents of Jihadists: Losing Children, Then Their Community
item.description: After a Muslim family’s twin daughters left England for Syria in order to join the Islamic State, they faced isolation from those in their community who feared even a tangential connection to terrorism.
item.dc:creator: By KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Alfurqan Islamic Center in Manchester. A mother from the congregation recently traveled to Syria in search of her daughters

item.title: A Leader of Shabab Surrenders
item.description: Zakariya Ismail Ahmed Hersi, who had a $3 million bounty on his head, turned himself in to the Somali police, an intelligence official said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: A Former Ground Zero Goes to Court Against the World’s Nuclear Arsenals
item.description: The Marshall Islands, the Pacific atolls where Americans once conducted nuclear tests, want to spur global disarmament in a case before the world’s top court.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By MARLISE SIMONS
item.media:description: The 1954 “Castle Bravo” nuclear test was among 67 conducted by the Americans in the Marshall Islands

item.title: That Debt From 1720? Britain’s Payment Is Coming
item.description: Prompted by record low interest rates, the British government is planning to pay off debts it racked up over hundreds of years.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: George Osborne, the chancellor of the Exchequer, wants to pay off bonds for debt from the 18th and 19th centuries.

item.title: North Korea Accuses U.S. of Staging Internet Failure
item.description: The North rejected accusations that it was behind the hacking of Sony Pictures and it called President Obama reckless “like a monkey in a tropical forest.”
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: President Obama and North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un. Each has accused the other of orchestrating Internet attacks.

item.title: World Briefing: Mexico: Body of Kidnapped Priest Is Found
item.description: State prosecutors in Guerrero opened an investigation Friday into the slaying of the Rev. Gregorio López Gorostieta, whose body was found on Christmas Day.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Sudden U.S. Thaw Worries Cuban Dissidents
item.description: As the United States and Cuba enter a period of unprecedented dialogue, many dissidents who stood with American officials in condemning the Castros contend that President Obama gave away too much.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By VICTORIA BURNETT and WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Cuban dissident group Ladies in White marched Sunday for the rights of political prisoners.

item.title: South Korea: 3 Die at Nuclear Plant’s Construction Site
item.description: Three South Korean workers died Friday after apparently inhaling toxic gas at a construction site for a nuclear plant being built by South Korea’s monopoly nuclear power company, which has come under recent threats by hackers, a company official said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Azerbaijan: Prosecutors Raid Radio Station Funded by U.S.
item.description: A radio station funded by the American government says its office in Baku, the capital, has been raided by prosecutors who claim to have a court decision to shut it down.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
